metadata.case_name: Mohatas (Decree-holders) v. Executors of Sukeshwari Ali and others

facts.text: Sukeshwari Ali possessed three plots of land bearing premises Nos. 26, 27 and 28, Dum Dum Cossipore Road prior to 1944 and left a will with defendants Nos. 1, 2 and 6 as executors.
Executors granted leases of the plots to defendants Nos. 3, 4 and 5 respectively and put them in possession.

Mohatas (appellants/decree-holders) claimed Sukeshwari had only life interest in lands vesting in them on her death; filed suit on September 15, 1944 against executors and tenants for declaration of no right to possess and khas possession by evicting defendants and removing structures.
Subordinate Judge at Alipore passed decree for khas possession in favour of Mohatas on March 30, 1948, giving defendants six months to remove structures.
Defendant No. 3 appealed successfully; no further concern with him or premises No. 26.

Executor defendants appealed; defendants Nos. 4 and 5 did not appeal. Concern only with defendant No. 4 (Bengal Breweries Ltd.) on premises No. 27 with factory; defendant No. 5 on No. 28 with temples.
Mohatas filed execution application on September 22, 1948 against defendants Nos. 1,2,4,5,6.
Subordinate Judge issued writ on September 25, 1948 for delivery of possession of Nos. 27 and 28 by removing persons bound by decree refusing to vacate; return fixed November 22, 1948.
Decree-holders applied for police help on September 28, 1948.
Executor defendants and defendant No. 4 applied for stay on September 29, 1948; adjourned to September 30 after assurance no execution till next day 2 p.m.
On September 30, 1948, executor stay dismissed (no power under O.41 r.5 CPC); defendant No. 4 stay dismissed but decree-holders undertook to allow normal business for six weeks for settlement.
Decree-holders deposited costs for police help on September 30, 1948; police requested for October 1, 1948.
Defendant No. 4 filed another stay and s.47 objection alleging tentative rent arrangement on September 30, 1948; adjourned to November 11, 1948.

On October 1, 1948, Nazir with police executed writ: entered premises No. 27 (gate opened by manager); amicable settlement for factory to run 6 weeks, settlement meantime, decree-holders' guards posted. Possession delivered at 10:30 a.m.
Nazir delivered possession of premises No. 28: priest amicably vacated temples, lands, etc.
Decree-holders executed receipt at 10:30 a.m. on October 1, 1948 acknowledging full possession of Nos. 27 and 28 including buildings, etc.
Executor defendants obtained ad interim High Court stay at 11:15 a.m. on October 1, 1948.
Subordinate Judge recalled writ provisionally on October 1, 1948 to November 5 pending formal stay.
On November 22, 1948: Possession delivered; third party (Bhairab Tewari) filed O.21 r.100 application re No. 28; execution posted after Misc. Case No. 13/1948.
High Court order on January 21, 1949: Defendant No. 4 to deposit costs if due within month, then 3 months to remove machinery and vacate No. 27 brewery; no stay for other items.
Executor appeal dismissed September 8, 1954.
Defendant No. 4 did not vacate after 3 months; criminal proceedings under CrPC s.144 did not affect possession.
Subordinate Judge order September 8, 1949: Decree-holder takes no other steps. Possession re Bengal Breweries delivered. Execution dismissed on part satisfaction.
Decree-holders fresh execution application against defendant No. 4 on September 27, 1951 for eviction from No. 27.
Defendant No. 4 objected under s.47 CPC: decree fully executed per 1949 order, no further execution.
Subordinate Judge dismissed objection May 20, 1953; High Court set aside April 5, 1955, dismissed execution.
High Court certificate June 15, 1956; appeal admitted August 3, 1956.
Supreme Court added Mool Chand Sethia, Tola Ram Sethia, Hulas Chand Bothra as respondents August 11, 1960.

Defendant No. 4 executed mortgages of No. 27: first May 25, 1944 to Coming Banking Corp.; others post-suit pre-decree. Assets to United Bank; suit, final decree May 30, 1955; auction July 20, 1956 purchased by bank; confirmed March 1, 1958; possession to bank; conveyed to added respondents July 13, 1960.
Defendant No. 4 not in liquidation, no appearance.

legal_issues.text: Whether the decree had earlier been executed in full against defendant No. 4 so as to bar fresh execution proceedings.
Whether added respondents have locus standi to contest the appeal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Preliminary objection: added parties have no locus standi.

Decree not fully executed on October 1, 1948 as defendant No. 4 not bodily removed; undertaking on September 30 prevented full execution; guards placed with permission; writ recalled; High Court order January 21, 1949 implies no full execution and estops respondents.
Execution partly done on October 1, interrupted, allowable to continue later; not fresh execution.

respondent_arguments.text: Decree fully executed per Nazir return, receipt, orders of November 22, 1948 and September 8, 1949; possession delivered though amicable with permission to continue business.
Once possession accepted without removal (not necessary if not insisted), cannot re-execute.

court_reasoning.text: Added respondents have locus standi as purchasers continuing appeal under s.146 CPC per Saila Bala Dassi.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right to continue appeal carries to transferees.

court_reasoning.text: Records show full possession delivered October 1, 1948 per Nazir return, receipt; defendant No. 4 bound by decree in possession; O.21 r.35 allows delivery without removal if not necessary/insisted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decree-holders accepted possession with permission to continue, posted guards, acknowledged receipt; bound by orders recording delivery.

court_reasoning.text: September 8, 1949 order binding: possession delivered re Bengal Breweries, execution dismissed on part satisfaction (full re them).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No challenge to orders; cannot go behind them.

court_reasoning.text: Undertaking reconciled as permission post-possession for 6 weeks; execution not stayed, proceeded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Removal not required if decree-holder accepts without.

court_reasoning.text: Not interrupted partial execution; guards indicate possession taken; gap over 2 years; fresh execution impermissible per Maharaja Jagadish Nath Roy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Symbolical possession accepted, no second khas possession.

court_reasoning.text: October 1 recall infructuous post-execution; January 21 High Court order not stay/ finding of non-execution; no estoppel as no representation by defendant No. 4 (no appeal).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interlocutory, no issue decided on execution.

holdings.text: Decree fully executed against defendant No. 4 / Bengal Breweries Ltd. on October 1, 1948; no further execution permissible re premises No. 27.
Added respondents properly on record with locus standi.

precedents_cited.case_name: Saila Bala Dassi v. Nirmala Sundari Dassi
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal proceeding under s.146 CPC; purchaser from appellant can continue appeal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maharaja Jagadish Nath Roy v. Nafar Chandra Parmanik
precedents_cited.relevance: Decree-holder accepting symbolical possession cannot later seek khas possession; no second execution.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Stay powers; objections to execution; delivery of possession (symbolical if accepted); third party claims; devolution of interest.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Criminal proceedings post-execution did not affect possession.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by decree-holders, upholding High Court: decree fully executed against defendant No. 4 in 1948 via accepted symbolical possession; fresh 1951 execution incompetent. Added respondents have locus.

key_quotes.text: "We then entered into the factory house and delivered possession in each of the buildings at about 10-30 a. m. Before removal of the furniture... amicable settlement... decree-holders men will remain there as guards."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Nazir's return proving delivery of possession.

key_quotes.text: "Received... delivery of possession of premises Nos. 7 and 8 formerly Nos. 27 and 28... including all buildings, tanks, gardens and temples, etc."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner

key_quotes.text: "Possession so far as regards the Bengal Breweries are concerned, delivered. Ordered that the execution case be dismissed on part satisfaction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Binding order recording full satisfaction re defendant No. 4.

key_quotes.text: "The decree-holders undertake that they will allow the company to carry on normal business for six weeks from today by which time the company will settle matter with the decree-holders."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
